title: Live updates | Jennifer Roberts, Edwin Peacock square off in mayoral debate
text:
Order Reprint of this Story 
Charlotte’s mayoral candidates Jennifer Roberts and Edwin Peacock are facing each other at The Charlotte Observer/WBTV debate, sponsored by Duke Energy, at McGlohon Theater in Spirit Square. 
Watch the debate here, at WBTV.com and on Bounce, Channel 1255 on Time Warner Cable. For minute-by-minute tweets from the event, scroll to the bottom. The 7:30 p.m. debate is scheduled to last about an hour. 
[Read more of the Observer’s election coverage.] 7:51 p.m.: After the Randall Kerrick case, why should public have faith in CMPD brass? 
Peacock said this is why he calling for a citizen’s task force and ride-alongs with officers. “We need city council members to understand what’s going on in their communities. There is a division in the police department. They are feeling the pressure. They need a city council and mayor to say we will hold you accountable.” 
Roberts: “I would say we have to do better. I am heartened to hear there is conversation with NAACP, Mecklenburg Ministries. I also know we are planning to have dash cameras expire. I am in favor of keeping both (dash cameras and body cameras).” 7:44 p.m.: When did you buck your own party? 
Peacock said he bucked the Republican party during his Congressional race, when he opposed Amendment One, which would have prohibited gay marriage. 
Roberts said she was the only Democrat to vote to re-do the Mecklenburg’s 2011 property revaluation. 7:37 p.m.: What would you say to areas of the city where you don’t have support? 
Peacock said the streetcar is dividing the city. 
Roberts addressed heavily Republican Ballantyne. “I will not support Ballantyne becoming a separate town,” she said. “I remember a time when I was a county commissioner, I went to a group in south Charlotte that are real estate investors. I thought ‘Oh goodness, I will have a hard time here.’ But I explained the choices the county had, and the value (to the county) that we are adding.” 7:34 p.m.: How does it feel to know that Bob Rucho has more actual power over city than you? 
Edwin Peacock said “leadership is about influence.” He said it starts with a strong relationship with delegation. 
Jennifer Roberts said she will work to be a regional mayor. “I want to re-activate the regional alliance of mayors that Anthony Foxx started. I want to have good relationships with regional delegations.” 7:30 p.m.: Why do you want to be mayor? 
Jennifer Roberts said she wants to run to bring opportunity to all corners of the city. Said she wants Charlotte to be a place where her children will want to live. Mayor is a recruiter, an advocate. 
“I look forward to serving,” she said. 
Edwin Peacock said he wants to make a positive change on Charlotteans lives. Said the mayor’s position is one of influence, but not of power. Want influence to be for positive growth. Background on debate 
Topics will include development, crime and transportation, including toll roads. The audience will be able to ask questions throughout the forum. 
Lightning rounds will include lighter topics such as the Panthers’ Super Bowl chances and their favorite local coffee shop. 
Roberts and Peacock are answering questions from a panel of journalists: Eric Frazier, The Charlotte Observer; Keith Larson, WBT radio; and Katie Toussaint, CharlotteFive.com. Live Blog Charlotte mayoral candidates meet in Observer/WBTV debate  ;
